title: Cokie Roberts, Longtime Political Journalist, Dies at 75
text:
Cokie Roberts, the daughter of Louisiana politicians who grew up to cover the family business as a pioneering journalist in the nation’s capital, died on Tuesday in Washington of complications from breast cancer. She was 75.

Over her decadeslong career at ABC News and NPR, Ms. Roberts became one of the most prominent political broadcasters of her era, a familiar figure to millions of Americans and an ardent champion of younger generations of women in the media.

“Cokie’s kindness, generosity, sharp intellect and thoughtful take on the big issues of the day made ABC a better place and all of us better journalists,” ABC News President James Goldston said.

ABC interrupted its regular programming to announce Ms. Roberts’ death, drawing an outpouring of condolences from many of the politicians that she had covered, including former Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama.

“Cokie Roberts was a trailblazer who forever transformed the role of women in the newsroom and in our history books,” House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) wrote on Twitter. “Over five decades of celebrated journalism, Cokie shone a powerful light on the unsung women who built our nation, but whose stories had long gone untold.”

Republican Sen. John Kennedy, a fellow Louisianan, lauded Ms. Roberts as “a pioneer for women in journalism.…My thoughts and prayers are with her family during this time.”

Ms. Roberts was the daughter of Hale Boggs, a former Democratic House majority leader from Louisiana, and Lindy Boggs, who succeeded her husband in Congress.

Ms. Roberts worked in local news and CBS News before joining NPR to cover Congress in 1978.

She joined ABC a decade later, while retaining a part-time role as a political commentator at NPR.

She co-anchored ABC’s Sunday political show “This Week” with Sam Donaldson from 1996 to 2002.

Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, said Ms. Roberts was a role model for women at a time the journalism profession was still dominated by men, and was a constant over 40 years of a shifting media landscape and changing world.

“She will be missed, and we send our condolences to her family,” Mr. Obama said.

Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, called Ms. Roberts a talented, tough and fair reporter.

“We respected her drive and appreciated her humor,” the former president said. “She became a friend.”

President Trump, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One while en route to California, said he respected Ms. Roberts’ professionalism, if not necessarily agreeing with her work.

“I never met her. She never treated me nicely,” Mr. Trump said. “But I would like to wish her family well. She was a professional, and I respect professionals.”

In 2016, Ms. Roberts requested that NPR to clarify her role as a commentator when she wrote a column calling on “the rational wing” of the Republican party to reject Mr. Trump as their presidential candidate. But her colleagues said she never became cynical or lost her love for politics.

Ms. Roberts, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2002, kept working nearly to the end. She appeared on “This Week” in August, drawing enough concern about her evident weight loss that she released a statement saying “I am doing fine” and was looking forward to covering next year’s election.

She co-wrote a political column for many years with her husband of 53 years, Steven Roberts.

Ms. Roberts also wrote several best-selling books focusing on the role of women in history. She wrote two books with her husband, one about interfaith families and “From This Day Forward,” an account of their marriage.

Ms. Roberts won three Emmys throughout her career and was named a “Living Legend” by the Library of Congress in 2008.

NPR described Ms. Roberts one of a small group of influential female journalists in the 1970s who revolutionized the broadcaster’s male-dominated culture, with many younger staffers referring to her as one of “the Founding Mothers” of NPR.

ABC News political reporter Jonathan Karl recalled being in awe of Ms. Roberts when he first started working at the network.

“When I think of politics, I think of Cokie Roberts,” he said.

Ms. Roberts was born in New Orleans in 1943. As the daughter of two former U.S. representatives, Ms. Roberts’s childhood was divided between in Louisiana and Washington, according to NPR. Her father served for three decades in Congress before dying in plane crash during a campaign trip to Alaska in 1972. Ms. Roberts’ mother, Lindy Boggs, took her husband’s congressional seat and served for 17 years, later becoming U.S. ambassador to the Vatican, according to NPR.

She attended Wellesley College and met her future husband at a conference for student leaders.

Ms. Roberts told Kentucky Educational Television in a 2017 interview that she had no regrets over pursuing a career in journalism instead of following her parents’ footsteps into a life of public service Congress.

“I do feel strongly that informing the voters about what’s going on, trying to explain it in ways that people can understand, and putting the issues out there is a form of participation,” Ms. Roberts said in the interview, according to NPR.

Ms. Roberts is survived by her husband and two children, Lee and Rebecca.
description: Cokie Roberts, the daughter of politicians and a pioneering journalist who chronicled Washington from Jimmy Carter to Donald Trump for NPR and ABC News, died Tuesday of complications from breast cancer. She was 75.
